entry.title: cTMS Setup for CPI
entry.content:
cTMS Architecture – Integration Suite (CPI)

Similar to transporting BTP Role Collections, the Content Agent Service can also be used to transport Cloud Integration (CPI) content.

While the overall setup remains largely the same, a few additional configurations specific to CPI are required.

Here we have four environments Dev, QA, UAT, and Prod, each corresponding to a separate BTP subaccount. We have provisioned the Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS) in a separate subaccount. The Cloud Integration team develop/configure their content and export the same from the Dev subaccount using Content Agent Service integrated with Cloud Transport Management Service (cTMS), which then adds the transport to the QA node. From there, it is imported into QA and the subsequent environments (UAT, Prod) through Solution Manager (SolMan), leveraging Focused Build (FB) or Charm status transitions.

Additionally, this setup can be integrated with SAP Cloud ALM

Setup Steps:

Since several of these SaaS applications share common setup steps, please begin by following the initial setup steps outlined here Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Step1: Enabling Content Transport

Enabling Content Transport involves the following major steps:

Step1a: Subscribe to Content Agent Service in Dev Subaccount

If you subscribe to Content Agent Service, you can trigger transports using it, if you want to use Cloud Integration to do that, you will have to setup additional destination, which was discussed in down section. 

Follow These Steps:

  1. Navigate to your SAP BTP Dev subaccount, where you want to subscribe to the Content Agent Service.

  2. From the left-hand navigation pane, go to: Services → Service Marketplace

  3. In the Service Marketplace, search for Content Agent.

  4. Select the Content Agent tile from the search results.

  5. Click Create 

  6. From the Plan dropdown, select free (the service type is preselected as Content Agent).

  7. Click Create to confirm the subscription.

  8. Click on Go Application to access Content Agent Service UI

From there you will be able to select the Content and export as transport using cTMS.

Step1b: Create Service Instance/key for Process Integration Runtime

Create a service instance/key for Process Integration Runtime to implement inbound communication.  This should be setup in source subaccount.

1. From the Dev subaccount that hosts your SAP Cloud Integration application → Navigate to Instances and subscriptions → create

Plan -  depending on your use case, select one of the following options, for our scenario, we used api plan

  • integration-flow
    Use this plan to define inbound authentication for senders calling the integration flow endpoint (on an SAP Cloud Integration worker node).

  • api
    Use this plan to define inbound authentication for API clients calling the SAP Cloud Integration OData API.

2. Select these roles in next section

Service Instance setup, create a Key and it is ready to use for "CloudIntegration" destination

Step1c: Selecting the Transport Mode

The content transport mechanism offers flexibility to move your integration artifacts using CTS+, cTMS and MTAR File Download to a local file system.

To enable a transport mode in Integration Suite:

  1. Go to Settings → Tenant Settings → Open the Transport tab → Under Transport Mode, choose the following :
    • Transport Management Service

Step2: Create a Service Instance and Key for Content Agent Service

In the Target SAP BTP account, where you want to perform Import you create the service instance and service key for the SAP Content Agent service with application plan. 

This service key will be used in creating Destinations. 

Note: Setup this in Source Subaccount also if you plan to setup Content Agent Destination for triggering transports from Cloud Integration

Step3: Create Content Agent Destination

You can skip creating this destination if you want to use the Content Agent Service's web UI to trigger the transport. If you want to trigger from Cloud Integration, this destination is required and it should be setup in Source BTP Subaccount. 

Name: Must be "ContentAssemblyService"

URL: https://content-agent-assembly.cfapps.<dc>.hana.ondemand.com

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: Provide the URL under UAA from the CAS service key details

Client Id & Secret - Use the Content Agent Service Key details to setup this Destination. 

Step4: Create Cloud Integration Destination

We need to setup this destination in Source Subaccount, where you perform export operations. 

Name: Must be "CloudIntegration"

URL: https://<cpitenant>.cfapps.<dc>.hana.ondemand.com/api/1.0/transportmodule/Transport

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: Provide the value of the oauth → tokenurl field from the Process Integration Runtime service key

Client Id & Secret - Use details from Process Integration Runtime service key 

Step5: Create TransportManagementService Destination

SAP Content Agent service supports content transport using SAP Cloud Transport Management. To enable this service to Export the content to the transport queue of cTMS, this destination must be created in the Source SAP BTP account with this name.  

Name: Must be "TransportManagementService"

URL: uri from the cTMS service key

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

Token Service URL: uaa → url from the cTMS service key 

Use the Client ID & Secret from cTMS Service Key. 

Step6: Create Destinations to CF Subaccounts

In the subaccount where the Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) service is subscribed, create a destination to each target BTP subaccount. We don't setup any destination for Dev subaccount. Dev node in cTMS will be virtual for this scenario. 

Name: Give appropriate name to resemble your CTMS Node

URL: https://content-agent-engine.cfapps.<dc>.hana.ondemand.com

Token Service URL: https://my-subdomain.authentication.<region>.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token

client id, secret -  use the details from Content Agent service key created in step2 above. 

Step7: Configure Transport Nodes in cTMS

Prerequisites

  • You have been assigned one of the following roles: Administrator or LandscapeOperator.

From the cTMS UI, you can define transport nodes to represent your system landscape. There are multiple ways to create a node:

You can either Create a node on the Landscape Visualization screen or from Transport Nodes screen. 

Allow Upload to Node: Enable this checkbox to allow file uploads to the node. Enabled for the Dev node only but in this scenario, Dev node will virtual. 

Forward Mode: Default value is Auto, You can change this setting based on your landscape and transport flow requirements.

Controlled by SAP Solution Manager: Select this checkbox only if you plan to integrate with SAP Solution Manager (e.g., Charm or Focused Build). We will only enable this for QA and upper environments.  When you enable this, it will not allow manual imports from cTMS UI, only through Charm/FB status change. 

Note: If you plan to integrate with Cloud ALM, do not check this option. 

Content Type: For Content Agent Service, select Multitarget Application archives.

Destination: Select the appropriate target destination you previously configured in your cTMS subaccount in Step6.

Step8: Create Transport routes in cTMS

In SAP Cloud Transport Management, transport routes are used to connect transport nodes.

Name: Provide the appropriate name

Chose the Source node & Target node and click on OK. 

Your landscape loos like this

Note: You can also use Transport Landscape Wizard, with which you can setup the all your landscape nodes & routes at a time.

Step9: Integrate with Solution Manager

To integrate Cloud Transport Management (cTMS) with SAP Solution Manager (Charm / Focused Build), follow the step6 from below article. 

If you want to integrate with Cloud ALM, follow the step7 from below article. 

 Setting Up Cloud TMS for Various SAP SaaS Solutions 

Conclusion:

I hope you learned, how to setup cTMS for CPI using Content Agent Service. Now the setup is complete and ready for transporting the content using  cTMS either integrated with SAP Solution Manager or Cloud ALM.

Thank you for reading  my article, feel free to provide any feedback or comment for any questions.

Thanks,
Raghu

entry.title: Re: Upadating VBFA Entries
entry.content:
Hi @Mahesh_0264 

Regarding your inquiry, I would advise against direct table updates in VBFA. This table is critical for SAP’s document flow consistency, and manual database updates can cause serious data integrity issues.

Instead, I recommended you make use of the standard SAP function modules or BAPIs designed to maintain delivery and document flow data consistently.

Alternatively, you also have the option to perform updates through standard transactions or interfaces that handle all related updates internally.

I hope this provides more clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

 

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/impact-of-manually-updating-vbap-and-vbfa-table/qaq-p/2520070

entry.title: Re: BADI to pick user name from the user ID in COUNT_LIST...
entry.content:
In SAP S/4HANA, especially in Extended Warehouse Management (EWM), the physical inventory count forms like COUNT_LIST and COUNT_LIST_RO are standard templates used for printing count sheets. These are typically used in manual inventory environments where RF devices or mobile apps aren't available. I could understand your challenge that you want to display a custom username in the PI count output format, and you've tried using the BAdI INV10_LIST_OF_STOCKS_FORM_I, but the username isn't appearing.

What you can do is in INV10_LIST_OF_STOCKS_FORM_I make sure

  • Your custom field is populated correctly in the BAdI logic.
  • You're assigning the field to the correct structure used in the form layout.
  • The form layout (Smart Form or Adobe Form) is updated to display the custom field.

Check the Form assignment via SPRO → Logistics Execution → Warehouse Management → Activities → Physical Inventory → Define Print Control. Here, verify that your custom layout is correctly assigned to the physical inventory document type

Based on your post, the system should work for UAE and you only see COUNT_LIST and COUNT_LIST_RO, it’s likely due to localization or system configuration. To activate or create additional forms:

  • Use transaction SFP (for Adobe Forms) or SMARTFORMS (for Smart Forms)
  • Copy the standard form and enhance it with your custom field
  • Assign the new form in customizing

By any chance, if you're still unable to retrieve the username, consider:

  • using SY-UNAME in your BAdI logic to capture the current user
  • storing the username in a custom table during PI document creation and retrieving it during form generation

entry.title: Things to consider during Concur Implementations
entry.content:
So how are you great people!! Today I thought of a scenario which we have successfully implemented for our clients which is not so difficult but if not designed properly can be a mess. We have all come across different scenarios while doing our Concur Implementations, from straightforward implementation to complex ones involving multiple integrations. In this blog I will like to explain one such scenario where we are bringing a new company into the existing Concur Instance. They will be roommates and will have their own individual policies and standards.

Introduction to the use case

So here's how it goes, there is a Company A which is using a Global Concur Instance for all its companies throughout the world. Now Company B which is basically a sister company having its own Concur instance decides to come into the existing Global Instance of Company A. Now the thing we have to remember here is, even though these are sister companies, they don't share any system with each other from HR system to ERP its all different. So this where the complexity lies in and where we need to put on our design cap and think before we start.

Steps to Follow:

Step 1: Custom Fields Audit:

Before we dive into the Requirement gathering phase, we have to do one audit of our existing instance which company A is using. We need to check how many custom fields are available, how many org fields are available, how many fields with the required data types are available and all that. Trust me this is the most difficult part of it all, there will be multiple places where we need to share the custom fields between the two instances.

Step 2: Primary Requirements:

Let start from the basics of the things that we need information about for this Company B. So your ORG structure is the most important stuff based on which you will get to know the countries in scope and how many levels of connected list you need to design. Since our Company A is using Org unit 1 to 3, we advised to have the org structure limited to the same 3 level format so that we can use Org unit 4 to 6 for country, Company and cost centers. One thing we need to communicate in the beginning to stake holders from Company B is we cannot use the authorized approver workflow as in feature Hierarchy, only one set of org units can be used for workflow. 

If you see below, the feature hierarchy can contain only one set of custom fields for authorized approver workflow, so it is important to communicate this at the start.

Please see the below screenshot where we have defined the connected list logic for the two companies using different set of custom fields.

We need to set up by creating the accounting hierarchy and create a new ledger if they are planning to use a different ERP system. 

Below you will see the accounting hierarchy set up for various companies based on their ledger preferences.

So once we get all the requirements locked, we will start as usual by creating groups, policy, forms and all the primary and secondary configurations as usual. The main thing to keep in mind during configuration of forms and fields is to make sure we are not disturbing the existing fields used for company A.

Important Considerations:

Another thing to keep in mind is during the Tax Configuration, this might be an issue if there a country in scope for Company B is already available in the system for Company A. The problem we might encounter is for example consider a country say Australia. For Company A, Airfare expense is configured to have a tax form with 3 tax rates, and for Company B same expense type has a standard tax rate for 10%. So what will happen in this case is even if try to exclude the company A while configuring the tax for Company B, since Tax is a country-based configuration, the tax form which is configured for Company A will be visible for Company B too even though it is not supposed to be.

Below you will see the screenshot where a single country can be configured with different reclaim codes based on their ERP .

 

So, the only solution to this is to create new expense types whenever there are countries we are bringing into the system which are already available in the instance.

Step 3: Integrations:

Once this is all done and all the other configurations completed, we need to work with the HR system for the company B for the integration. We need to provide all the required custom fields to the HR system's technical team so that mapping is completed and we get the daily import of 305 and 350 data. 

Here in the below screenshot, you can see how the Employee load with the 305 and 350 files are sent over to concur from two different HR systems, one is UKG and the other is Workday based on the respective HR systems the individual company uses.

Similar way the payment extract job needs to be setup for which we need to raise a ticket with Concur and provide all the group names for the company B which we have configured. While this is happening, we need to connect with the ERP team to map our SAE extract by providing the list of custom fields which are to be mapped in the ERP system.

Now we need to do multiple rounds of testing for company B, so that we make sure all the account codes, workflow, audit rules are working well and also need to test the posting into the ERP system. Also don't forget to do a round of regression testing for the Company A.

Conclusion:

By doing the above steps , we can bring in any new company into our existing instance even though they are supposed to follow a completely different set of configurations similar to Roommates, will share the same instance but they have different set of things for each other.

I hope I made the things clear from configuration point of view, and please let me know if you need to know any more details.

Until next time, Ciao!!

entry.title: Re: Upadating VBFA Entries
entry.content:
While it may seem straightforward to update VBFA-RFMNG_FLO directly, this table is tightly integrated with SAP’s document flow logic. Manual updates can compromise data integrity and lead to downstream errors. Instead, I recommend investigating the root cause at the transaction level—such as delivery or billing inconsistencies—and using SAP’s correction reports to resolve them safely. This ensures the system remains consistent and auditable.

Direct updates can break document flow integrity, leading to:

  • Inaccurate reporting
  • Inconsistent status updates
  • Errors in downstream processes (e.g., billing, returns)

SAP provides standard correction programs like SDVBUK00, RVDELSTA, RVV05IVB, for document flow inconsistencies. Execute these reports in QA and see how it works.

entry.title: Re: Vendor Basic details are not showing in FBL1N (List D...
entry.content:
Hi @kirankumark2 

Thank you for your question.

Based on the details you provided, the screenshots confirm that the described issue is not data-related but it seems to be tied to List Output display logic. These are likely caused by; a possible output layout reset or lost field bindings after upgrade, an SAP standard program RFITEMAP changes in SP31 affecting header field retrieval or a custom enhancement for header fields that was not reactivated after upgrade.

I would recommend you carry out the following:

First, in your List Output, test using SAP standard layout via Settings → Layout → Manage. If details show, rebuild your user layout.

Then compare your RFITEMAP’s current version to pre-upgrade to check header fetch logic changes.

Thereafter, run SU53 to confirm no authorization object is blocking the intended vendor master header fields.

Search relevant OSS notes for “FBL1N list output header missing” for SP31.

Please note, if you have custom code adding header details, ensure it is active and adjusted for SP31.

After carrying out these steps, this targeted check should help restore header details in List Output while preserving all existing post‑upgrade changes.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

After posting incoming payment for a down payment request, the system considers the entire value of the regular invoice for squaring-off the down payment amount. It does not give us any option to choose how much of that amount we would like to square-off this time against the invoice line items. If we convert the BDR into Preliminary Billing Document (PBD), it allows to modify the invoice line item, but not the down payment line item, which does not serve the purpose. Is there any way to bring the set-off procedure to manual mode ?

As a result, while trying to post incoming payment, system recognizes the net amount to be zero and gives the following error message. This would not have happened, had it allowed me to choose the down payment amount getting squared-off.

entry.title: Re: Define Release Procedure for Contracts
entry.content:
Try with the below approach

  • Go to CT04 to create a Characteristics. Let it be 'NETVALUE' for contract value. Assign field: CEKKO-GNETW.
  • Go to CL02, select Class Type 032 and assign the above NETVALUE to Class
  • Create Release Groups via SPRO → Materials Management → Purchasing → Purchase Requisition → Release Procedure → Define Release Groups
  • Create Release Codes and assign it to users who approve the Contract
  • Create Release indicators for example, 1 = Blocked and 2 = Released
  • Define Release Strategy like contract value > ₹1,00,000, Assign release group, release codes, and indicators, Maintain classification to link strategy with characteristic values
  • Finally, you can integrate with SAP Business Workflow to notify approvers automatically

entry.title: SAP Datasphere Automation : Creating Database user in SAP Datasphere using Datasphere CLI & Python
entry.content:
Introduction

One way to access datasphere hana database is via database users. Each database user is linked to one space (except database analysis user). We can create database user vai GUI however, its a long process and prone to errors. In this blog, i will share my work on how i automated the process using SAP Datasphere CLI and Python without the need to login into datasphere GUI.

Old Process:

If you want to create a database user via GUI, you need to perform the below steps.

  1. Login into the datasphere tenant. Make sure you have the required application roles to perform the task.
  2. Go to Space management and select the space. Scroll down and click create in database user. 
  3. Provide the username and deploy the space. Save the password and share it with the user. 

Automated Process

To overcome the long process, i have divided the python script to perform all these task in sequential manner. 

  1. Datasphere CLI Setup : Set the CLI and login into datasphere
  2. Reading the metadata: Read the space metadata using SAP Datasphere CLI space read command
  3. Modifying JSON : Enhance the output JSON with the new user details and deploy it using the space create command
  4. Password Reset : Reset the database user password and save it in a file for sharing.

Set up SAP Datasphere CLI (First time only)

To start working with Datasphere CLI, we need to perform few one time configuration like setting host, login in and setting cache. If you want to login via a different tenant, you need to change the CLIENT_ID and CLIENT_SECRETS as per the tenant.

datasphere config set host {"host_url"}
datasphere login --client-id {"client_id"} --client-secret {"client_secret"}
datasphere config set cache --client-id {"client_id"} --client-secret {"client_secret"}

 Once you are done with the initial setup of CLI, we can start working on the main code which will create database users.

Reading space metadata

Since we do not have a direct command to create DB user, we extract the space metadata JSON using CLI. This command output the space metadata JSON into console. I have stored this into a variable that i will use later in modifying the JSON

space_Json = datasphere space read -space "{space"} --definations

Modifying the JSON and deploying it in datasphere 

To create a new databased user in space, we need to add the new user details in the dbuser object of the JSON. We can store the space metadata JSON into our local machine and modify it or we can modify it on the go using tempfiles. I have used the later approach as it eliminates the need of JSON management 

#Concatenating the space and username
new_db_user = f"{space}#{username}"

#Appending the new_db_user details into the space metadata JSON
space_JSON[space]["spaceDefinition"]["dbusers"][new_db_user] = {
"ingestion":{
        "auditing":{
          "dppRead":{
            "retentionPeriod":21
            "isAuditPolicyActive":True
          },
         
        }
      },
      "consumption":{
        "consumptionWithGrant":false,
        "spaceSchemaAccess":True,
        "scriptServerAccess":false,
        "localSchemaAccess":false,
        "hdiGrantorForCupsAccess":false
}

Once the JSON is modified, write the new JSON into a temporary file. I have stored the file path into a variable called tmp_file_path. I will push this file path to datasphere tenant.

#Pushing the modified JSON to datasphere tenant
datasphere space create --file-path "{tmp_file_path}" -- force-defination-deployment

If you want to delete a database user, remove the entry from the JSON and run the same command and add --enforce-database-user-deletion in the end. If this command is not added, then the deletion will not work.

Password Reset

Once the database user is created, we need to reset the password to store it in a local file for sharing. Below is the command to perform that action

datasphere dbusers password reset --space{"space"} --databaseuser {"new_db_user"}

 (Tip: Add a 30 seconds wait time between creating the database user and resetting the password commands because the space deployment takes some time and we cannot reset the password before that).

I have also added an automatic email creation in my workflow and inserting database user details into a local table for future analysis.

Conclusion:

With this automation, we can create database users in datasphere tenant without even login into datasphere. This workflow provides a more robust way to handle creation and maintenance database users. 

I would love to know your thoughts on this workflow in the comments below. Lets explore more opportunities of automation using datasphere CLI.

entry.title: Pagination concept in OData - ECC for SP - 7.3
entry.content:
Summary

This technical blog will open option to include pagination concept in Odata Service running on ECC system.

Introduction

This article is specific for developer who are still developing Odata Services on ECC on Pagination Concept.

There are multiple blogs available  on Pagination on S4 system but eventually same concept or logical approach is challenging while working in the ECC system.

How pagination works in S4 HANA system

Will talk on the existing solutioning part on S4 end before we come to ECC.

There are two keywords being used to restrict the count - one is $top and the other is $skip.  Both of the them play roles to restrict the count. I will not go in details about their operations as there are already existing blogs on it.

In S4, above keywords are used in the follows syntax to perform Pagination.

 

      SELECT <field1>,
                  <field2>,
                  ...          ,
                  ...          ,
                 <fieldn>
          FROM <SAP DB table>
         ORDER by <Key_field>
         INTO TABLE @<internal_table>
        OFFSET @paging-skip UP TO @paging-top ROWS.
 
Challenge in ECC system
But when it comes to ECC, above syntax difficult to apply directly as SKIP & ROWS are being used with OFFSET and UPTO keywords, which are not applicable for SAP-ECC system.
 
Solution
But, there are other approaches to handle paging in ECC. Here instead of restricting at the time of data fetch using SELECT query, will narrate how paging can be used using SAP standard class.
Below steps to follow to implement pagination in ECC system.
1. Pull TOP & SKIP from IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT into work area.
2. Use PAGING Method of SAP Utility Class - /IWBEP/CL_MGW_DATA_UTIL.
3. Pass work area with TOP & SKIP in PAGING method.
 
Working Code is below
******************Data Declaration ***************************

DATA: WA_PAGING TYPE /IWBEP/S_MGW_PAGING.

******************Assign Top & Bottom***********************

WA_PAGING-TOP = IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT->GET_TOP( ).
WA_PAGING-SKIP = IO_TECH_REQUEST_CONTEXT->GET_SKIP( ).

****************Call Data Utility Class*************************
CALL METHOD /IWBEP/CL_MGW_DATA_UTIL=>PAGING
  EXPORTING
       IS_PAGING = WA_PAGING
  CHANGING
      CT_DATA = <ENTITY_SET>.  "This table can be EntitySet of Odata Service

 
Conclusion
CT_DATA will have only specific number of counts (Skip & Top) as specified in the URI.

entry.title: Re: Engineer to Order - On premise VS Public Cloud
entry.content:
Hi @gunadharshini 

The 6GD scope item in the Public Cloud is a standardized, fixed-scope Engineer-to-Order process which was designed for cloud environments. It includes predefined configurations, limited customizations, simplified process flows, and embedded project production integration. Please note, upgrade and maintenance are managed by SAP and are updated quarterly.

In contrast, the ETO process in On-Premise systems offer full flexibility and customization options which supports complex routing, BOMs, and project-specific manufacturing requirements. It is important to note that customers have full control over configuration, user-exits, custom code, and upgrade timings.

There are major differences which includes configuration flexibility, level of process standardization, reporting capabilities, master data management, and upgrade or maintenance models.

Should you require more process and configuration guidance on 6GD, I recommend you consult the SAP Signavio Process Navigator which is accessible through SAP for Me. You can also consult the SAP Roadmap Viewer documentation.

I hope this provides the desired clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

Hi @Arpita1 

 

The "unsubscription failed" error you’re encountering when trying to unsubscribe from Integration Suite in your SAP BTP trial account is commonly due to residual runtime service instances or subscriptions that must be deleted first.

I suggest you take the following steps:

In your SAP BTP cockpit, go to your subaccount --> Instances and Subscriptions.

Make sure to delete all Integration Suite-related service instances and subscriptions, including runtime and connectors.

Then, wait a few minutes to ensure complete cleanup of the resources.

Finally, retry the unsubscription or new subscription of the Integration Suite capability.

If the deletion is not possible or unsubscription errors persist, create a new trial subaccount and provision Integration Suite there.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Partial set-off of down payment against regular custo...
entry.content:
In the Public Cloud edition, many backend configuration paths (like customizing for down payment clearing) are not exposed to customers. This includes:

  • Manual control over down payment application
  • Editing down payment settlement lines in billing documents
  • Customizing the clearing logic or settlement rules

This is by design, as SAP restricts certain flexibility in Public Cloud to maintain standardization and reduce complexity.

Some workarounds are

You can post a partial down payment using the Allocated Amount field in the Post Incoming Payments or Clear Incoming Payments app. This doesn’t solve the settlement control but helps manage cash flow.
Get some inputs from this SAP Learning 

If feasible, restructure your billing plan to:

  • Split the invoice into smaller chunks
  • Align down payment requests with specific billing items
  • Avoid full automatic settlement by controlling invoice timing

Since this is a functional gap, SAP encourages customers to submit a Customer Influence Request to enable manual control over down payment settlement in billing documents. You can do this via the SAP Influence Portal

entry.title: Re: Difference in Call Behavior Between Single-Cycle Plan...
entry.content:
To answer your question why the Single-Cycle plan generated all Work Orders is because, A single-cycle plan is time-based. When you schedule it with a start date in the past (e.g., 11.08.2024), SAP calculates all missed cycles up to the current date and generates backdated calls (work orders). This is standard behavior for time-based plans: SAP assumes maintenance should have occurred at each interval.

Coming to Multiple-Counter plan, a multiple-counter plan is performance-based, relying on measuring point readings (e.g., operating hours, mileage). Even if you define a 3-month cycle, the system does not generate historical calls unless you have measurement documents (via transaction IK11) that reflect usage over time. Without historical counter readings, SAP assumes only the current reading is valid and schedules only one call.

In other words, time-based plans look backward, while counter-based plans look forward based on actual usage data.

entry.title: Re: Intercompany Billing related to reassigned revenues i...
entry.content:
Based on your post, what is happening is that when you use the “Reassign Costs and Revenues” app to move revenue from one WBS element to another across company codes:

  • SAP generates an intercompany invoice on the sender side.
  • The receiver side gets a negative invoice (i.e., a debit memo with a negative amount), which reduces liabilities.

But what you actually need is a credit note on the receiver side to reflect the revenue increase properly.

This behavior is rooted in how SAP interprets intercompany revenue reassignment:

  • The system treats the reassigned revenue as a reduction in liability rather than an income transfer.
  • The invoice with a negative amount is technically correct from a debit/credit standpoint, but it doesn’t match the business expectation of a credit note.

To enable proper intercompany billing for revenues, make sure these scope items are active:

These are non-standard scope items and must be explicitly activated via the Manage Your Solution app

The other option would be to use Resource-Related Intercompany Billing. SAP has introduced a new resource-related intercompany billing process that improves traceability and handling of such scenarios. It allows:

  • Better control over billing documents
  • Clearer separation of cost vs. revenue flows
  • Potential for margin handling and credit note generation

If the system still generates a negative invoice:

  • You may need to manually adjust the document type or use a custom billing type that behaves like a credit note.
  • Alternatively, consider using journal entries to reflect the revenue transfer more accurately in financial statements.

Check these documentations

New Resource-Related Intercompany Billing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud blog by @varsha_chetanmanu 
Intercompany Cost Allocations and Billing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud blog by @Ulrich_Hauke

entry.title: Re: Implementing Data Flows in SAP Datasphere: Concepts and Examples
entry.content:
Hello @saravananc2 

nice blog, and very well explained!

But your overview is missing one big advantage of a data flow, in contrast to a replication flow!

In my example, I built a demo model, based on imported tables & views (via json file) from another tenant. There, some standard CDS views (delta extraction) got extended by custom fields.

If you try to connect the same CDS Views from another S4 system without the extensions, the replication flow refuses to be created unless you can connect each and every source field to the target table field. In my case this was not possible and I did not want to, since it was demo only, anyway.

The solution was to include the CDS view into a data flow, because it does not care about connecting all fields. For my purpose some 2 or 3 full loads have been sufficient.

I think you should emphasize this in your blog, that it comes with this advantage in contrast to replication flows.

BR, Martin

entry.title: Driving Breakthrough Results with Automated Root Cause Analysis on Event Graphs
entry.content:
When your KPIs drift off target, it’s tempting to focus on the numbers alone - but that’s like checking the thermometer without knowing what’s causing the fever. In today’s competitive landscape, organizations need to move past simply seeing their processes and start understanding why performance gaps occur. Automated Root Cause Analysis (RCA) on Event Graphs delivers that edge: zeroing in on bottlenecks, uncovering inefficiencies, and revealing the changes with the highest improvement potential. It’s like moving from a blurred snapshot to a high-definition view of your operations, giving you the clarity to act decisively, accelerate time to insight, and achieve measurable, breakthrough results.

The Elusive Efficiency Goal: When Traditional Process Analysis Hits a Wall 

The promise of process mining was always clear: identify bottlenecks and inefficiencies that drag down performance. You invest in dashboards, slouch over reports, meticulously map your processes hoping to pinpoint exactly why your order fulfillment is lagging or your accounts receivable turnover is sluggish. But what happens when your diligently crafted dashboards only tell half the story? What happens when the sheer volume of data overwhelms your ability to find the needle in the haystack? In today's complex organizations, hundreds of activities and events comprise even the simplest processes. Manually comparing variants to pinpoint the root cause of deviations from the target becomes not just tedious, but utterly impossible. Traditional tools leave you staring at the "what" while the elusive "why" remains out of reach. Decision-makers are left with gut feelings, not data-driven insights. Process analysts drown in data, without a clear path to actionable solutions. 

You've likely been there: staring at a dashboard flashing red, knowing something is wrong, but feeling utterly powerless to pinpoint the source. It's like having a persistent cough, but no doctor can diagnose the cause. You're stuck treating the symptoms, not the disease 

From Surface-Level View to Deep Dive: X-Raying Your Processes with Event Graph Analysis 

Automated Root Cause Analysis on Event Graphs isn't just another dashboard; it's an x-ray for your business processes. It dives deep into event logs, reconstructing the precise sequence of events driving - or hindering - performance. It's about understanding precisely why things happen. For example, you could pinpoint: 

  1. The hidden rework loop draining your resources: Are applications constantly being sent back for missing information, creating a cycle of wasted time and effort? RCA reveals the source of the problem and helps you streamline the process. 
  2. The impact of processing sequence on order fulfillment: Is performing credit checks after order picking leading to delays and cancellations when orders are rejected? RCA can highlight the negative impact of suboptimal sequences and identify opportunities for improvement. 
  3. Untapped automation potential: Are employees spending valuable time on repetitive, manual tasks like data entry or report generation? RCA can pinpoint these areas ripe for automation, freeing up your workforce for higher-value activities. 

This granular insight empowers decision-makers and equips process owners to surgically remove bottlenecks. Imagine dissecting invoice processing with unprecedented clarity. Event Graph Analysis illuminates every step, handoff, and decision point, revealing the cascading impact of each event. 

The "Aha!" Moment: Unmasking Hidden Bottlenecks and Igniting Transformation

Remember that frustrating KPI that refused to budge? Automated RCA delivers the "Aha!" moment, the breakthrough you've been striving for. Imagine finally uncovering the exact  sequence of events causing those persistent payment delays or identifying the single misconfigured step responsible for crippling your order fulfillment. This granular level of insight transforms guesswork into data-driven certainty, empowering both decision-makers and analysts to target interventions with laser focus. 

Armed with this newfound clarity, you can finally address the root causes of inefficiency and unlock transformative improvements. Fix the bottleneck, streamline the workflow, and watch your KPIs not just improve, but soar. Transformation isn't a distant aspiration; it's the inevitable consequence of understanding your processes at their core. 

Beyond Quick Wins: Embedding Root Cause Analysis for Continuous Transformation

Automated Root Cause Analysis isn't just a one-time fix; it's a continuous improvement engine. By embedding this capability into your process optimization strategy, you create a dynamic feedback loop, constantly learning, adapting, and optimizing your operations. For decision-makers, this means fostering a data-driven culture where insights fuel innovation. For process owners, it's the key to proactive process management, anticipating and addressing emerging bottlenecks before they impact performance. 

 

Imagine your processes as a living organism, constantly evolving, adapting, and thriving in a complex ecosystem. With Automated Root Cause Analysis on Event Graphs, this vision becomes a reality. Request a demo today and embark on a journey of continuous transformation.

entry.title: Cloud ALM and 3rd party application for requirement management.
entry.content:
Since my company has several development branches in IT, we would like to move to a unified requirement management system. This would mean that SAP application development and project management would remain under Cloud ALM, but requirement management would be moved to a single application (possibly ARIS) that would also manage other development branches.

The question is whether such a setup could be implemented in Cloud ALM, where requirement management is handled by another application, while other project management components would still be managed in Cloud ALM (project management, test management, document management, etc.).

Has anyone had a similar experience or implemented interfaces between Cloud ALM and 3rd party applications?

Could someone from SAP comment on this?

Thank you.

Martin Gajdos

entry.title: Re: SAP Fiori for SAP S/4HANA – App Variants are the EASY way to control App Features
entry.content:
Dear @Leslie_Castle Leslie (and @Jocelyn_Dart ),

In respond to this blog, I would like to share my initial opinion about the upgrade-safety of the methodology described. My concerns lay in the area where we assign the App Variant to our Business Users by duplicating entries inside the business catalog (and breaking the reference) by adjusting the SAPUI5 Component ID of the Tile/TM.

Note: In this Blog you also adjust the Semantic object & Action, which I believe is not technically required if you remove the original app from the role. **

Even though I do agree that UI-adaptations as itself relay stable during upgrades, I'm likely to encounter resistance when advocating for the large-scale adoption of App-Variants within the IT organization, especially as we transition toward a clean-core mentality.

In our organization (End-user), I want to plea for a UX strategy where we set an extraordinary focus on two of the Fiori Design Principles (Role based and Simple). To get that done, I want to propose the use of SU24-variants, automated test scripts and optionally the UI-Adaptations / App Variants; Your introduction (second paragraph) hits the nail on the head for me. This indicates the importance of this blog! Thank-you. 

Every year we upgrade our system, and we manually validate our custom technical catalogs. We do manual checks on semantic objects, actions and parameters, which I believe is necessary to validate (preferably as a pre upgrade activity). At this moment, we do not apply the ‘role-based’ and ‘simple’ UX strategy and we have only 3 custom tiles/TM’s and 2 adapted tiles/TM’s in /UI2/FLPAM.

Note: For the business catalog containing references to the standard tiles/TM’s, we do not have to do these manual checks since there is no broken reference which is upgrade proof.

In our organization we see a growing demand of SAP Fiori Apps. And I wish to get the technical execution of my UX proposal done with a high focus on adapting the tiles/TM’s using /UI2/FLPAM_ADAPT (because this should keep our adaptations upgrade proof from a technical point of view). Within this tool, we can adapt tile/TM descriptions, parameters and more in an upgrade-safe environment; However, we cannot adapt the ‘SAPUI5 Component ID’, which is where we fill in the ‘app-ID’ from an app variant management perspective.

If we embrace this strategy, we are talking about hundreds of custom tiles/TM’s inside our custom technical catalog; Imagine all of them with broken references.

This leads me to the conclusion that: Internally, as a content administrator, I'm cautious about justifying my proposal to emphasize the Role-Based and Simple Fiori Design Principles by relying on UI adaptations and app variants, as this approach technically leads to breaking references.

Therefore, I decided to reach out to all experts, by replying on this blog post. I would like to know how other experts think about this or if I missed something in my thoughts from strategy to solution. Also, I would like to prepare myself to submit a case (CA-UI5-FL-RTA?) or to make a proposal in the SAP Influence Program by collecting feedback and suggestions. Or should I forget UI-adaptations and rely on authorization objects which may make UI elements visible as well (I have no experience with that)?

By the way; One thing that I have tried to solve my problem is to create a SAP Fiori Launchpad Plugin that dynamically overwrites the ‘SAPUI5 Component ID’. Also, I could not find a sufficient Badi; I did not find a way to provide the variant ID as a URL-parameter. An adaptation project in the BAS sounds a little bit too rough for this case and will arise a lot of new questions, but it is a workaround I have investigated and may work instead.  

**About this note: I am mentioning this because changing the Semantic object & Action also leads to a broken reference. Duplicate semantic object / actions should not lead to inconsistencies if the user has access to only one of them; I don’t know if it technically impacts the behavior in this case, but I do know SAP recommends avoiding duplicates. I am aware that this recommendation also impacts my vision when it comes to hosting multiple variants of apps. So maybe, having the possibility to provide the app variant ID as a not-overwritable-TM-parameter would do the trick.
